hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Still bone dry. Even for street photography, too quiet out there lately.
Film’s nearly impossible to get now. Used to be better.
Everyone’s hiding, cameras or no cameras.
Finally caught one decent shot through a fogged window.
Yeah, dry as yesterday’s bread.
I take photos on film—old habit, keeps me sharp.
So much tension, nobody wants to be seen these days.
Lost half a roll dodging patrols by the camp.
Hard to tell stories when people turn their faces.
Dry, cold, you name it.
I shoot analog street photos. Still hiding rolls in my shoes.
The camps for the wiped families—I tried to capture it all on film.
People tense up when they spot the camera now. Different kind of fear.
Security swept through; almost lost my camera.
I saved one shot. The whole mood changed after.
Dry and thick with static. Good for shadows, bad for trust.
Street photography’s my thing—analog, real film, no edits.
Since the erasures started, my camera’s seen more truth than my eyes.
Those vanished camps—they let me take one group shot. Felt like history burning.
Patrols nearly caught me developing it, so I hide prints at Bar 101 now.
Film’s almost impossible to replace. Can’t risk state labs.
Those blurred faces—still more real than anything on broadcast.
Not just dry—like everyone’s holding their breath out there.
Photography’s more than a hobby—it’s how I remember who’s left.
I work with analog film. No digital, no BCI trace. That’s survival now.
I risked a shot at the Vanished’s camp last week—real faces, real fear.
Tucked my camera in a trash bin to dodge a patrol sweep.
Developed it in a borrowed flat, chemicals still on my hands.
I share the shots through dead drops. Old resistance tricks from my parents’ day.
Truth’s a risky business. These are the only records that matter now.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still shooting film. Not much left to shoot, though.
Lost a roll last week. Harder to get decent shots now.
Everyone’s nervous. Cameras make people duck for cover.
I keep it quiet. Nobody likes a lens these days.
Things feel different since those camps appeared.
Still at it. Film’s harder to find than food rations now.
People get jumpy when I pull out the camera.
Security’s everywhere after those BCI erasure stories broke.
I don’t develop in studios anymore. Too many eyes.
Had a shot almost confiscated near that protest camp.
Makes me wonder who’s really watching me sometimes.
Yeah, still chasing them. Analog’s all I trust for real stories.
Makes it tricky now—lots of folks in the camps don’t want to be seen.
Had to dodge a patrol yesterday, almost lost my camera.
Film’s expensive, and developing’s a risk by itself.
But sometimes people ask for their photo—proof they exist, you know?
Can’t upload anything, so I stash the negatives wherever I can.
These last few weeks... it’s not just about art, it’s survival.
Always. Analog’s memory can’t be wiped like their servers—real record, real people.
Last week a girl slipped me her camp’s only photo ID. Told me, keep it safe.
Security scans faces at every protest now—capturing someone’s image is almost an act of trust.
I’ve got to process film in bathrooms or abandoned shops, because labs are monitored.
I lost track of the number of erased families I’ve photographed lately.
Even rebels check my ID twice. No one trusts a lens, not anymore.
Honestly, sometimes I shoot for their sake, not even mine.
These days, photos mean more to them than to the newsfeeds.
Every shot I take lately, I wonder if it’ll be the last.
Started with my mom’s camera, years before BCI became gospel.
Film’s a liability now, but it’s the only proof some folks have left.
I hid rolls in hollowed-out books after the first erasures hit.
Near the vanished camps last Thursday, a family lined up—begged me for prints, anything.
Security drone nearly caught me after that. Spent hours hiding in a boiler room.
Not glamour, just survival. Each face on film might vanish tomorrow.
I give copies to people I trust—insurance against memory holes.
Feels like we’re archiving extinction, not just life. But that’s the point, isn’t it?
